{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15250,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola biflora, commonly known as twoflower violet or alpine yellow violet, prefers moist but well-drained soil. It requires regular watering to maintain consistently moist conditions, especially during dry spells or hot weather. However, be cautious not to waterlog the soil as this can lead to root rot. A good practice is to water when the topsoil feels slightly dry to the touch. Reducing water frequency during the plant's dormant period in winter may be necessary, depending on the environmental conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola biflora thrives in partial shade to full shade conditions, mimicking its natural alpine and woodland habitats. It does best with filtered sunlight or dappled shade, such as beneath the canopy of trees or larger shrubs. In hotter climates, it is crucial to protect the plant from intense afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves and reduce flowering. However, in cooler regions, it can tolerate some morning sun or indirect light to flourish best."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Viola biflora is minimal, but it can benefit from occasional deadheading to encourage further blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. Remove spent flowers and any damaged or yellowing leaves to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Towards the end of the blooming season, you can cut back the plant to help it conserve energy for the following growth cycle. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Twoflower Violet","description":"Viola biflora is a species of the genus Viola. It is also called alpine yellow-violet, arctic yellow violet, or twoflower violet. It is found in Europe, Siberia, Central Asia, Pakistan, western and northern China, North Korea, Japan, and Western North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Twoflower Violet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Viola biflora"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15746,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago patula, commonly known as swamp goldenrod, thrives in moist soil conditions. It is important to keep the soil consistently wet, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. The plant prefers soil that is rich in organic matter and can tolerate standing water for short periods. However, ensure that the plant doesn’t remain waterlogged for too long as this may lead to root rot. In drier periods, increase watering frequency to maintain soil moisture, but reduce it in the winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago patula is adaptable in its sunlight needs, thriving best in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight a day for optimal growth and robust flowering. In shadier conditions, the plant may grow taller and produce fewer blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun will help produce the most vibrant floral displays. However, some afternoon shade can be beneficial in extremely hot climates to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago patula is primarily about maintaining the plant's shape and encouraging healthy growth. After the flowering season in late fall, cut back the stems to tidy up the appearance and remove any spent flowers, which can prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if needed. Deadheading throughout the blooming season can also promote a second flush of blooms. Remove any dead or diseased foliage as necessary to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Swamp Goldenrod","description":"Solidago patula, the roundleaf goldenrod or rough-leaved goldenrod, is a species of goldenrod found in wetlands, especially swamps, fens & sedge meadows. It is native to most of the eastern United States, as far west as Wisconsin and Texas. There are two subspecies.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Swamp Goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rust","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago patula"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15846,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helvella macropus, a type of fungi, does not require regular watering like plants. Instead, it thrives in natural outdoor environments where moisture is naturally available. If attempting to cultivate this fungus, ensure the growing substrate remains moist but not waterlogged. Consistent high humidity levels mimic its natural habitat, promoting healthy growth. Avoid direct watering to prevent disturbing the delicate mycelium structure."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helvella macropus generally prefers shady environments typical of its natural woodland habitats. It should be kept out of direct sunlight, which can dry out the fungus and surrounding substrate. If artificially cultivated, place it in a location that mimics these conditions—indirect, dappled light works best. Maintaining a dark, humid environment replicates the protective shade under a canopy where it likes to grow."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike plants, Helvella macropus does not require pruning. Its maintenance involves ensuring optimal growing conditions such as appropriate substrate, moisture, and humidity. Any visible dead or decaying fruiting bodies should be removed to prevent mold or disease. Allow this fungus to follow its natural growth and decay cycle, intervening minimally to support its ecological role and lifecycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"long-stalked gray cup","description":"Helvella macropus is a species of fungus in the Helvellaceae family, Pezizales order. Ascocarps can be found in summer and autumn in woodland, usually (though not exclusively) associated with broad-leaved trees. The slender stem, up to 5 centimeters high, supports a cup shaped cap, the whole fruiting body being pale grey or brown, the inner (hymenial) surface of the cup usually being darker.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["long-stalked gray cup"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Helvella macropus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14851,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Obolaria virginica prefers moderately moist soil, meaning it does not like to dry out completely between watering. However, it is also important to avoid waterlogging the soil, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, check the soil regularly and aim to keep it consistently slightly damp. In its natural habitat, this plant might receive regular precipitation, so try to mimic these conditions by watering whenever the top inch of soil begins to dry but not letting it sit in standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Obolaria virginica thrives in dappled to partial shade conditions, which mimic its native woodland environment. It generally does well in areas that receive filtered sunlight through trees or in spots with morning sun and afternoon shade. Too much direct sunlight can scorch its leaves and lead to stressed growth, while heavy shade might hinder its flowering. Aim to provide it with approximately 2-4 hours of indirect sunlight daily for optimal growth and to support its delicate blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Obolaria virginica is usually minimal, as it is a small, herbaceous perennial that does not become woody or overgrown. Since it naturally dies back to the ground after the growing season, simply remove any dead or yellowing foliage as it appears to maintain a clean appearance and prevent any fungal diseases. If you wish to prevent self-seeding, remove spent flowers before seeds develop. Pruning is not necessary for shape or size control due to its modest growth habit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pennywort","description":"Obolaria virginica, commonly known as Virginia pennywort, is a species of flowering plant in the gentian family. It is monotypic, with no other species in the genus Obolaria.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["pennywort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Obolaria virginica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15647,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Megaskepasma erythrochlamys prefers consistently moist soil, so water it regularly ensuring the soil doesn't dry out entirely. It's essential to maintain a balance, avoiding waterlogged conditions which could lead to root rot. During the growing season, especially in warmer months, increase the frequency of watering. In contrast, during the winter or dormant periods, allow the soil to slightly dry between waterings. Using well-draining soil is crucial to support healthy root growth. Always adjust watering practices based on the plant's environmental conditions and signs of overwatering or underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Megaskepasma erythrochlamys thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. However, for optimal growth and vibrant flowering, it is best to provide it with at least a few hours of filtered sunlight each day. Avoid direct harsh sunlight, especially in hot climates, as this may scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, place the plant near a bright window with indirect light. When grown outdoors, a spot with dappled shade will help prevent leaf burn while allowing enough light to support growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Megaskepasma erythrochlamys is essential to encourage bushier growth and remove dead or damaged branches. Prune the plant after it finishes flowering by cutting back overgrown stems to maintain its desired shape and size. Use clean and sharp pruning tools to prevent disease spread. Regular pruning helps prevent the plant from becoming leggy and promotes a fuller appearance. Additionally, remove any dead flowers to prevent unnecessary energy expenditure on spent blooms. Observe the plant's structure and prune accordingly to ensure good airflow around the stems."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Brazilian red-cloak","description":"Megaskepasma is a monotypic genus of plants containing the single species Megaskepasma erythrochlamys, known by the common name Brazilian red-cloak. It is native to Venezuela and elsewhere in South America, a free branching, upright showy tropical shrub to 3 m high, with appressed reddish hairs; stout stems with broad ovate leaves 12-30 cm long, dark green with pink midrib. It is grown as an ornamental shrub in climates from warm temperate to tropical, for its inflorescence,...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Venezuela"],"other_name":["Brazilian red-cloak"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Megaskepasma erythrochlamys"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14554,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"For Symphyotrichum lateriflorum, commonly known as calico aster, moderate watering is essential. This plant prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate brief dry spells once established. Water the plant deeply but allow the top 1-2 inches of the soil to dry between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided, especially in clay-heavy soils, to prevent root rot. In drought conditions or particularly hot climates, increase the frequency of watering, but make sure excess water can drain away to avoid waterlogged soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum lateriflorum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, aim to provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, especially in cooler climates. In hotter regions, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat and potential scorching. Full sun conditions generally result in the most robust flowering displays, but partial shade is beneficial in areas with extremely hot summers. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures healthy growth and a bountiful bloom."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum lateriflorum involves routine deadheading and the occasional cutback to maintain its shape and health. After the blooming period, you can cut back the stems to the base to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Removing spent flowers and dead stems throughout the growing season can help promote continuous blooming. For shaping or size control, early spring before new growth appears is the best time to prune, as this helps stimulate vigorous and compact growth for the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"calico aster","description":"Symphyotrichum lateriflorum (common name calico aster or starved aster) is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae, native to eastern North America. A. diffusus, A. vimineus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["calico aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum lateriflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15547,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus montezumae, commonly known as Montezuma pine, requires less frequent watering compared to other plants, as it is adapted to dry climates. It is crucial to let the soil slightly dry out between waterings, especially once the tree is established. Newly planted pines should be watered more often to help establish a strong root system, about once a week, decreasing as the tree matures. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. In general, ensuring that the soil has good drainage will help maintain the health of the tree."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Montezuma pine thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. This species is well-suited for areas with high sun exposure and does not perform well in shade, as it could lead to weak, spindly growth. Ensure the planting site has abundant sunlight throughout all seasons to support the tree's health and growth. While it is hardy, providing adequate sun exposure aids in the development of a strong structure and vibrant foliage, critical for the tree’s longevity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"While Pinus montezumae does not require heavy pruning, light pruning is beneficial to maintain its shape and health. Remove dead or damaged branches anytime they are noticed to prevent disease spread. Late winter or early spring is an ideal time to prune, as the tree is dormant. Avoid cutting the central leader as this can affect the tree’s shape. Focus on removing any crossing branches and thinning out dense areas to improve air circulation. Pruning should always be minimal to avoid unnecessary stress to the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Montezuma pine","description":"Pinus montezumae, known as the Montezuma pine, is a species of conifer in the family Pinaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Montezuma pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus montezumae"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular pruning can stimulate bushier growth and help maintain shape. It's best to prune in the early spring, removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, which minimize shock and the risk of introducing disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14355,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave parryi, like many succulents, is drought-tolerant and requires infrequent watering. It is crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions to prevent root rot. Depending on the climate, watering once every two to three weeks is usually sufficient, and water should be applied directly to the soil rather than on the leaves. During winter, when the plant becomes dormant, reduce watering even further, possibly to once a month, as this plant prefers dry conditions during this season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave parryi thrives in bright, full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions where the sun's intensity is very high, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. This plant may be grown in partial shade but will grow more slowly and may become leggy, seeking out light. When growing indoors, a sunny, south-facing window is ideal to replicate its natural conditions. Ensure the plant is gradually acclimatized to direct sunlight to avoid any leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave parryi is generally minimal. Remove dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant’s appearance and to prevent pest issues. This can be done at any time of the year with sterilized tools to avoid infections. Pruning should focus primarily on removing leaves that are dry or show signs of disease. Be cautious of the plant's spiny edges and sharp tips, which can cause injury. For mature plants, remove the flower stalk after blooming to tidy the plant, though flowering is a rare event for Agave parryi."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Parry's agave","description":"Agave parryi, known as Parry's agave or mescal agave, is a slow-growing agave native to Arizona, New Mexico, and northern Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Parry's agave"],"pest_susceptibility":["Agave Weevil","Snout Weevil"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Agave parryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15446,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Verbascum lychnitis, commonly known as White Mullein, is a drought-tolerant plant requiring minimal watering. In its growing season, mainly spring and early summer, watering is only necessary if there is a prolonged dry spell. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant sits in waterlogged conditions. Once established, it typically thrives on natural rainfall. Reduce watering in fall and winter, as the plant enters dormancy. It's best to water deeply yet infrequently, ensuring that the soil dries out thoroughly between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbascum lychnitis requires full sun to thrive, which means it needs at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Planting it in the brightest spot available will ensure the best growth and flower production. Inadequate sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced blooming. This plant is quite adaptable to a variety of light conditions, but the quality and quantity of blooms are greatly improved with more sunlight. In regions with extremely hot afternoon sun, some light shade may be beneficial, although full sun exposure is preferred for optimal performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Verbascum lychnitis is not extensive but beneficial for encouraging more blooms and maintaining plant health. Deadhead spent flowers during the blooming season to promote further flowering and often a longer flowering period. In late fall, cut back the stems after flowering has finished to tidy up the plant and reduce the risk of disease. Clear away any dead or damaged foliage throughout the year to maintain a tidy appearance and potentially prevent pest infestations. Wearing gloves while pruning may be helpful, as the foliage can sometimes cause skin irritation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Mullein","description":"Verbascum lychnitis, the white mullein, is a flowering plant in the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae) native to Asia and Europe.​​ It has naturalized in parts of North America.​​ The species was first formally named by Carl Linnaeus in 1753.​ Despite its common name, the flowers can be white or yellow.​","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Central Asia"],"other_name":["White Mullein"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Verbascum lychnitis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14753,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Russula parvovirescens is a type of wild mushroom typically found in humid, forested environments, as it requires a moist substrate to thrive. In cultivation or a garden setting, it's crucial to ensure the substrate, which could include decaying leaf litter or organic compost, remains consistently moist. Avoid waterlogging by ensuring good drainage, as standing water can lead to decay or fungal pathogens. Regular misting can maintain the required humidity. Always allow the top layer of substrate to dry slightly between watering, simulating its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Russula parvovirescens typically grows in shaded woodland areas, so it's essential to mimic these conditions in any cultivation or indoor growing environment. Provide indirect or diffused light, rather than direct sunlight, which can be too harsh and cause the substrate to dry out quickly or harm the delicate structures of the fungi. Natural dappled sunlight, like that found beneath a forest canopy, is ideal. If growing indoors, using a shaded area or an indirect light source will better replicate their natural habitat, promoting healthy development without stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Russula parvovirescens in the same way it is for flowering plants or shrubs, as mushrooms generally do not require pruning. However, if you're cultivating these fungi and they exhibit symptoms of overcrowding or decay, you may gently clear away older, decayed mushrooms to make room for healthier growth. Avoid disturbing the mycelium network underground. Regularly inspecting your cultivation space and removing any other invasive mold or fungus can also be beneficial for healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blue-green Cracking Russula","description":"Russula parvovirescens is a basidiomycete mushroom of the genus Russula. Found in the eastern United States, it was described as new to science in 2006. It is similar in appearance to the more widespread Russula virescens and R. crustosa, but can be distinguished from those species by its smaller stature, and microscopically by the voluminous terminal cells of the cap cuticle.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Blue-green Cracking Russula"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Russula parvovirescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In locations with intense sun, providing some form of protection, such as planting under trees or alongside other taller plants, can be beneficial. Providing the right balance of shade and indirect light helps maintain its distinctive foliage color and growth habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex platyphylla is relatively simple and mainly involves cleaning up old foliage to maintain its neat appearance. During late winter or early spring, trim back any dead or damaged leaves to make way for new growth. This can be done using sharp scissors or shears for cleaner cuts. Regular removal of any yellowing or browning leaves throughout the growing season will also help keep the plant looking tidy. Avoid cutting back the plant too severely, as this can hinder its natural growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"broad-leaved sedge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["broad-leaved sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex platyphylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During summer dormancy, its sunlight needs are minimal. For optimal growth, especially in early spring, ensure that the plant is positioned where it can receive morning sun. This will enhance blooming and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Puschkinia scilloides is minimal. The primary activity involves deadheading spent flowers during or after the blooming season in spring. This practice helps to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production and encourages a neater appearance. After the foliage has yellowed and died back naturally, it can be removed to maintain the plant's appearance and hygiene. Avoid removing green foliage, as it is necessary for photosynthesis which stores energy for the next growing season. Pruning tools should be sterilized to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"striped squill","description":"Puschkinia scilloides is a bulbous perennial, native to Western Asia and the Caucasus (Turkey, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, North Caucasus, Transcaucasus and Iran).","family":null,"flower_color":"White, Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Turkey","Iran","Caucasus"],"other_name":["striped squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Puschkinia scilloides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14654,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heliconia rostrata requires consistent watering to maintain its vibrant growth. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, which extends from spring to late summer, water the plant more frequently, approximately two to three times a week. In contrast, reduce watering during the dormant winter months, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Using well-drained soil and pots with drainage holes helps prevent root rot. Misting the leaves can also keep humidity levels adequate, especially in dry indoor environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heliconia rostrata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. In its native tropical environment, it grows under the canopy where it receives filtered light, so replicating these conditions is ideal. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, it's best to avoid harsh sun exposure, especially during the peak afternoon heat, which can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or south-facing window, where it can get ample light without direct sun, works well. If the plant is outdoors, consider placing it under partial shade to protect it from intense sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heliconia rostrata helps to manage its size and appearance and encourages healthy regrowth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves regularly to promote better air circulation and light penetration. After flowering, cut the spent flower stems at the base to allow new growth to develop. It's also beneficial to thin out clumps to prevent overcrowding. Pruning is typically done in the late winter or early spring before the new growing season begins. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease and encourage healthy recovery."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hanging Lobster Claw Heliconia","description":"Heliconia rostrata (also known as hanging lobster claw or false bird of paradise) is an herbaceous perennial native to Peru, Bolivia, Colombia, Costa Rica, and Ecuador, and naturalized in Puerto Rico. Other Heliconias grow in the upright position (e.g. Heliconia bihai), their cup-shaped flower bracts storing water for birds and insects. This plant, however, has downward-facing flowers, the flowers thus providing a source of nectar to birds.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America","Central America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["Hanging Lobster Claw Heliconia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Rhizome Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Heliconia rostrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells or hot weather, ensuring the soil does not dry out completely. However, avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. A general rule of thumb is to water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering, particularly in hotter climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia elegans thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish and produce vibrant blooms. Adequate sunlight is crucial for its growth and to maintain its aromatic foliage and colorful flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia elegans is important to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Trim back any dead or damaged stems to the base, and cut back healthy stems by a third to promote branching. Regular deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also promote a longer blooming period and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Pruning helps control the size of the plant and enhances flowering throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Pineapple Sage","description":"Salvia elegans, commonly called pineapple sage or tangerine sage, is a perennial shrub native to Mexico and Guatemala. During dry spells, providing supplemental water is beneficial, particularly in its growing seasons from spring to early summer. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, as the plant is sensitive to excess moisture. Light pruning can also encourage better airflow through the branches and improve the tree's shape. This plant can be pruned in late winter or early spring, but avoid heavy pruning as it can shock the tree or shrub. In areas with milder temperatures, they can be gradually acclimatized to more direct sunlight. However, too much full sun exposure can stress the plant and lead to browning edges. When grown indoors, place them near bright, indirect light. Adjust their positioning based on environmental conditions and observe the plant's response to ensure optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ardisia escallonioides is mainly done to maintain its shape and health. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, removing any dead or diseased branches. Light pruning encourages a dense growth habit and keeps the plant tidy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is essential to ensure the pot has adequate drainage and to err on the side of underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pediocactus simpsonii thrives in full sun conditions, which mimic its natural high-altitude, desert habitat. Insufficient sunlight may lead to etiolation, where the plant stretches and loses its compact form. During excessively hot summer days, providing some afternoon shade can prevent potential sunburn, but generally, the more sun exposure, the better this cactus will grow and bloom effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not necessary for Pediocactus simpsonii as it grows naturally into a compact, globular form. However, if you notice any dead or damaged parts, especially after a cold winter, they can be gently removed to prevent any fungal infections. Use sterile tools to avoid introducing pathogens, and take care not to damage the healthy part of the plant. Occasionally, offsets or pups may appear; these can be removed if propagation is desired, or they can be left to form clusters over time."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Ball Cactus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Mountain Ball Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pediocactus simpsonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown in forests or tighter groupings, ensure that the upper canopy receives enough light and that the trees are spaced adequately to avoid excessive shading."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus pseudostrobus is generally minimal, as these trees have a naturally attractive shape. Primary pruning tasks should focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health and appearance. For younger trees, if shaping is required, selectively prune to maintain a balanced appearance and encourage a strong structure. Always use sharp, clean tools to make your cuts, and avoid cutting into the trunk or main branches to reduce stress on the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"smooth-bark Mexican pine","description":"Pinus pseudostrobus, known in English as the smooth-bark Mexican pine and in Spanish as chamite or pacingo, is a tree endemic to Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["smooth-bark Mexican pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine beetles","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pinus pseudostrobus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14357,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pelargonium triste prefers a well-draining soil and requires moderate watering. Allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot, as it is sensitive to overwatering. During the growing season, water thoroughly but ensure good drainage. In its dormant period, which occurs in its natural summer habitat, watering should be significantly reduced. In regions with winter rainfall, a similar watering pattern as the Mediterranean climate should be followed, keeping the soil on the drier side during summer unless heavy indoor work is being done."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pelargonium triste thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to encourage healthy growth and flowering. In very hot climates, providing some protection from the intense midday sun can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Indoors, placing the plant near a south or west-facing window can ensure it gets ample sunlight. If the plant receives insufficient light, it may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. During the dormant phase, it’s okay if the sunlight exposure decreases slightly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pelargonium triste involves trimming back any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth. This can be done throughout the growing season. To maintain shape and promote bushier growth, pinch back the growing tips regularly. Pruning should also include removing any spent flowers to prevent the plant from expending energy on seed development, which encourages further blooming. In late autumn or early winter, a more significant trim can be done to ready the plant for its resting period. Use clean, sharp tools to avoid infection or damage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Night-scented Pelargonium","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Night-scented Pelargonium"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Pelargonium triste"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14454,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carludovica palmata, commonly known as the Panama hat plant, thrives in consistently moist soil. It is crucial to maintain regular watering, allowing the topsoil to dry out slightly between sessions to prevent root rot. This plant is native to tropical environments, so it enjoys higher humidity levels. During warmer months, you may need to water more frequently to keep the soil from drying out completely, while in cooler months, you can reduce watering, but never let the soil dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carludovica palmata prefers bright, indirect light but can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the morning when it's less intense. Avoid exposing it to harsh afternoon sun as it may scorch the leaves. If you're growing it indoors, a spot near a north or east-facing window works well. While it can handle lower light conditions, its growth rate may slow down, and the plant may not thrive as vigorously. Ensure a consistent light source to mimic its natural tropical environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Carludovica palmata is generally minimal but necessary to maintain a healthy and attractive plant. You should remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage better growth and airflow through the plant. It's best to prune in the growing season, spring through summer, using clean, sharp scissors or shears to cut the leaves near the base. Avoid cutting too much at once; instead, trim incrementally over time to prevent over-stressing the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toquilla palm","description":"Carludovica palmata (Panama hat plant or toquilla palm) is a palm-like monocot plant. It is not a true palm. Its leaves are different from the leaves of true palms, and unlike true palms it does not develop a woody trunk. Its female flowers (which mature first) have large stigmas, and its male flowers (which mature later) have a lot of pollen. They reproduce vegetatively, because they do not produce viable seeds.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["toquilla palm"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Carludovica palmata"],"soil":["Well-drained soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14755,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gagea lutea, commonly known as Yellow Star-of-Bethlehem, prefers moist but well-drained soil conditions. Water the plant adequately to keep the soil slightly moist, especially during its active growth period in spring. Avoid waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to bulb rot. During its dormant period in summer, reduce watering significantly since the plant's water requirement diminishes. Ensure that the plant does not dry out completely, maintaining a moderate moisture level until the next growth season. Using a light mulch can help retain soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gagea lutea thrives in partial shade environments, mimicking its native woodland habitat. Ideally, it should receive morning sunlight with shaded conditions during the harsher afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorch. Full shade can result in less robust blooms or diminished flowering. It can adapt to a mixed light setting, such as beneath deciduous trees where it gets early spring sunlight before the trees leaf out. Therefore, it’s important to ensure it gets ample indirect light during its growth phase for optimal flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Gagea lutea, pruning is not typically necessary for this perennial bulbous plant. These plants die down naturally after flowering, so it is best to allow the foliage to yellow and wither naturally post-bloom. This process ensures that the plant reabsorbs nutrients stored in the leaves back into the bulb for next year’s growth. If desired, remove any dead or diseased leaves to prevent any potential diseases or pests from harboring. However, avoid cutting back the green foliage until it is completely spent."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Star-of-Bethlehem","description":"Gagea lutea, the Yellow Star-of-Bethlehem, is a Eurasian flowering plant species in the family Liliaceae. It is widespread from Spain and Norway to Siberia and Japan.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Yellow Star-of-Bethlehem"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Bulbs","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Gagea lutea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15649,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Oenothera perennis, commonly known as the small sundrops, thrives in well-drained soil environments and prefers to have consistent but moderate watering. This plant is quite drought-tolerant once established, making it ideal for gardeners who may occasionally forget to water. To keep your Oenothera perennis healthy, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid overwatering, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During periods of extreme heat or drought, increase watering frequency slightly, but ensure the soil drains well to prevent stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera perennis prefers full sun exposure to thrive, which means it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant is well-suited to open garden areas that bask in sunlight for most of the day, making it an excellent choice for sunny borders or rock gardens. While it can tolerate partial shade, it may not bloom as prolifically without sufficient sunlight. For optimum growth and to promote vibrant yellow flowers, place your Oenothera perennis in a sunny location with minimal obstruction from larger trees or structures that may cast prolonged shadows."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera perennis involves occasional deadheading to encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. Trim the spent flowers with a pair of sharp scissors or pruning shears close to the base of the flower stem. This practice not only keeps the plant looking tidy and vigorous but also redirects its energy towards producing more healthy blooms. Additionally, at the end of the growing season, you can cut back the plant to just above the basal foliage to help it stay neat during its dormant phase and prepare for new growth in the spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Small Sundrops","description":"Oenothera perennis is a species of herbaceous flowering plant native to the eastern United States and Canada. Its common names include little evening primrose, small sundrops, and small evening primrose.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Small Sundrops"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Oenothera perennis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14556,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sirococcus clavigignenti-juglandacearum is not a plant; it is a fungal pathogen known to affect walnut trees, specifically the butternut tree (Juglans cinerea). Therefore, it does not require watering care. Instead, managing the health of affected trees involves proper tree care practices such as ensuring adequate water supply to the host tree to maintain its overall health, and removing infected plant parts to reduce the spread of the pathogen."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The fungus affects the trees regardless of the sunlight condition. However, general care for walnut trees includes ensuring they receive full sunlight, as healthy, well-exposed trees might better withstand infections. Ensure that the surrounding environment of the tree supports good air circulation, as this can help minimize fungal growth and spread. Trees should be planted in locations that maximize their exposure to natural light, thus supporting overall tree health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning to manage this pathogen involves removing infected branches as soon as symptoms are detected to prevent further spread. It's crucial to sterilize tools between cuts to avoid transmitting the fungus. Dispose of pruned material carefully, away from healthy trees, to minimize spore dispersal. Winter or early spring, when the tree is dormant, is the optimal time for pruning. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree and make it more susceptible to infections."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"butternut canker","description":"Sirococcus clavigignenti-juglandacearum is a mitosporic fungus that causes a lethal canker disease of Butternut trees (Juglans cinerea). Known in the vernacular as Butternut Canker, it is also known to parasitize other members of the Juglans genus on occasion, and very rarely other related trees including hickories. The fungus is found throughout North America, occurring on up to 91% of butternut trees, and may be threatening the viability of butternut as a species.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["butternut canker"],"pest_susceptibility":["Butternut canker"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sirococcus clavigignenti-juglandacearum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its initial growth phase, it should be watered deeply and consistently once a week to help develop a robust root system. After it becomes established, natural rainfall is often sufficient. It's important to avoid overwatering, as Bear Oak prefers well-drained soils and excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In drought conditions, supplemental watering once every 10-14 days may be beneficial to maintain its health and foliage quality."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus ilicifolia thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sun exposure daily for optimal growth and development. It is adapted to a variety of soil conditions but performs best when planted in well-drained, sandy, or rocky soils where it receives ample sunlight. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and fewer, less vibrant leaves. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy growth. Additionally, thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as Bear Oak benefits from maintaining its natural form. Light shaping and clearance of ground level suckers can also help in managing its growth, but excessive pruning can stress the plant and affect its overall vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bear oak","description":"Quercus ilicifolia, commonly known as bear oak or scrub oak, is a small shrubby oak native to the eastern United States and southeastern Canada. The name ilicifolia means \"holly-leaved.\"","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Acorn\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bear oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus ilicifolia"],"soil":["Loamy","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious of overwatering, especially if planted in clay soil or pots without adequate drainage. After the flowering period, cut back flower stalks once they have withered. This helps prevent seeding and reallocates the plant’s energy back to the bulbs. During late fall or early winter, leave the foliage intact, as it provides energy storage for the plant’s next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Drummond's Onion","description":"Allium drummondii, also known as Drummond's onion, wild garlic and prairie onion, is a North American species of onion native to the southern Great Plains of North America. A position that receives dappled sunlight or is shaded for most of the day will help mimic its natural habitat, resulting in a healthier, more robust plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Corydalis scouleri is minimal and generally involves removing spent flower stalks and dead or damaged foliage. This helps to tidy the plant and can encourage a tidier growth habit and possibly a longer blooming period. In late summer or fall, after blooming, you can cut back the flowering stems close to the base of the plant. Regular maintenance might include removing any yellowing leaves to promote healthy growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15749,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tigridia pavonia, commonly known as the peacock flower, requires careful watering to thrive. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist during its growing season, typically spring and summer, but ensure it is not waterlogged as this can lead to root rot. Water deeply but allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between watering. In winter, when the plant is dormant, water sparingly, just enough to prevent the bulbs from drying out completely. Always use well-draining soil to aid in preventing excess moisture retention, which is detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Tigridia pavonia prefers warm, sunny environments to flourish and encourage vibrant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in extremely hot climates, full sun exposure ensures the best flowering performance. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, it may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Ensure that outdoor plantings are in locations with unobstructed sunlight, and indoor pots are placed in south or west-facing windows to maximize sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tigridia pavonia involves removing spent blooms and dead foliage to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's appearance. After the flowering period, cut back the stems to ground level if they begin to yellow or die back naturally, as this signifies the onset of dormancy. Avoid cutting green foliage as it helps in storing energy in the bulb for the next growing season. Regularly remove any wilted flowers to prevent seed formation. This not only neatens the plant but also diverts the plant's energy into bulb and root development rather than seed production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tiger flower","description":"Tigridia pavonia is the best-known species from the genus Tigridia, in the Iridaceae family. Common names include jockey's cap lily, Mexican shellflower peacock flower, tiger iris, and tiger flower. The species is widespread across much of Mexico as well as Guatemala, El Salvador, and Honduras. The species is also considered naturalized in Ecuador and Peru.","family":null,"flower_color":"Various, including red, orange, pink, yellow, and white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Tiger flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails","Aphids"],"propagation":["Bulb division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Tigridia pavonia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15550,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus arizonica, commonly known as Arizona pine, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. During the first few years after planting, water deeply and infrequently to promote root development. Once mature, this drought-tolerant pine is best watered only during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it's important to let the soil dry out between waterings. In general, aim to water every few weeks during dry periods, ensuring that the water reaches deep into the soil, which encourages robust root systems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus arizonica thrives in full sunlight and should be planted in a location that receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This pine species is well-suited to bright, arid climates characteristic of the southwestern U.S. While it can tolerate some shade, full sun exposure ensures optimal growth and overall health. If the tree is planted in an area that receives insufficient sunlight, it may become leggy and produce fewer branches, impacting its overall aesthetic and vigor. Therefore, ensuring ample sunlight is crucial to promoting the healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinus arizonica should be minimal and primarily focused on maintaining the tree’s shape and removing any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth starts. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid damaging the tree. Remove any crossed, broken, or rubbing branches to open up the canopy and allow for good air circulation. It's important not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree and potentially open it up to disease and pest problems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona pine","description":"Pinus arizonica, commonly known as the Arizona pine, is a medium-sized pine in northern Mexico, southeast Arizona, southwest New Mexico, and western Texas in the United States. It is a tree growing to 25–35 m tall, with a trunk diameter of up 1.2 m (3 ft 11 in). The needles are in bundles of 3, 4, or 5, with 5-needle fascicles being the most prevalent. This variability may be a sign of hybridization with the closely related ponderosa pine...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Arizona pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Pine bark beetles"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Pinus arizonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15253,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melaleuca nesophila prefers a regular watering schedule, especially during its first growing season to establish a healthy root system. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant, but it will perform best with regular watering in dry periods, particularly when planted in sandy or well-drained soils. It is important not to over-water as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings but ensure that the plant does not wilt. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally and produce abundant flowers. Melaleuca nesophila is adaptable but performs best in sunny positions which help stimulate active and compact growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may reduce flowering intensity. Ensuring ample sunlight exposure will also aid in its drought resistance and minimize the risk of fungal diseases, as it enhances the drying of foliage after rain or watering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Melaleuca nesophila should ideally be done annually, after the flowering period has ended. It helps maintain a desirable shape and enhances flowering in the following season. Regular trimming can promote denser growth and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and the plant's overall health. Light pruning can be done to maintain shape, but avoid cutting too far back into the wood, as this can inhibit growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Showy Honey-myrtle","description":"Melaleuca nesophila, commonly known as showy honey-myrtle, mindiyed or pink melaleuca, is a plant in the myrtle family, Myrtaceae and is endemic to an area near Albany in Western Australia. The Noongar name for the plant is mindiyet. Hardy and adaptable, with a dense crown of leaves and prolific heads of pink or purple flowers in late spring and summer, it is one of the most commonly cultivated melaleuca shrubs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Showy Honey-myrtle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Melaleuca nesophila"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15850,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zinnia peruviana thrives with regular watering but should not be overwatered. It's important to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, maintain moderately moist soil, but reduce watering in the winter, allowing the plant to have a dry period. In particularly hot or dry conditions, increase the frequency of watering slightly. Ensure that the plant has well-draining soil to allow excess water to escape and to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zinnia peruviana requires full sunlight to produce the most vibrant and plentiful blooms. Ideally, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimum growth. If grown indoors or in partially shaded areas, the plant may exhibit leggy growth and produce fewer flowers. In regions with particularly intense sunlight, some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming dehydrated. Ensure it is planted in a location where it will receive ample light throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zinnia peruviana is not strictly necessary but can help promote bushier growth and more vibrant blooms. Pinch back young plants once they have formed two or three pairs of leaves to encourage branching. Throughout the blooming season, deadhead spent flowers regularly to encourage continuous flowering and improve plant appearance. At the end of the blooming season, you can cut back the plants to about six inches to tidy the garden or to prepare for overwintering if the plant is not grown as an annual."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Peruvian zinnia","description":"Zinnia peruviana, common name Peruvian zinnia, is an annual flowering plant in the family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America","Peru"],"other_name":["Peruvian zinnia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Zinnia peruviana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. During the growing season, increase watering frequency, and be cautious not to let the soil dry out completely. In winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering but keep the soil slightly moist. It is important to maintain good drainage to prevent root rot. Utilize distilled or rainwater if possible, as tap water may contain minerals that orchids are sensitive to."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnadenia conopsea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, similar to its natural alpine meadow environment. It requires exposure to light throughout most of the day to encourage flowering but should be protected from harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. Ideally, place the plant in a spot where it receives morning sunlight and is shaded during the hottest part of the afternoon. If grown indoors, an east or west-facing window is suitable, ensuring the plant receives ample light without direct exposure during peak sunlight hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gymnadenia conopsea involves minimal maintenance. Routine care includes removing any dead or diseased leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. At the end of the blooming season, once the flowers have faded, the flower stems can be cut back to encourage new growth in the following season. Ensure you use sterilized, sharp pruning tools to prevent infection. It’s best to perform pruning activities during the growing season. Clean any debris that falls around the base to prevent pest attraction and ensure air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fragrant Orchid","description":"Gymnadenia conopsea, commonly known as the fragrant orchid or chalk fragrant orchid, is a herbaceous plant of the family Orchidaceae native to northern Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Fragrant Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gymnadenia conopsea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14658,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Silene nutans, commonly known as the Nottingham Catchfly, prefers well-drained soil and tolerates drought conditions, making it suitable for xeriscaping. When watering Silene nutans, it's crucial not to overwater, as the plant is adapted to dry environments. Water this perennial sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, water may be required once every one to two weeks, but frequency should decrease significantly during the winter months when the plant is dormant. Always check the top few inches of soil for dryness before deciding to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silene nutans thrive best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, these plants should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight each day to promote strong, healthy blooms. However, they can tolerate light shade, especially in hotter climates where some afternoon shade can protect the plant from extreme heat. When choosing a planting site, consider an east or south-facing location that provides ample sunlight but offers some respite during the peak afternoon hours. Ensuring the plant gets adequate sunlight is key to supporting its natural growth cycle and floral display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silene nutans involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased foliage to encourage new growth and maintain plant health. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth starts. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, throughout the blooming season helps promote additional flowering and reduces the risk of seed dispersal for this potentially self-seeding plant. It's also beneficial to thin out overcrowded plants in the autumn to ensure better air circulation, which helps to prevent fungal diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or shears to make clean cuts close to the base of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Nottingham Catchfly","description":"Silene nutans is a flowering plant in the genus Silene, most commonly known as Nottingham catchfly.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Nottingham Catchfly"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Silene nutans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14558,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platycerium superbum, commonly known as the Staghorn Fern, needs consistent moisture but should not be overwatered. It's important to let the medium in which it's mounted or potted dry out partially between waterings. Typically, this means watering approximately every 1 to 2 weeks, depending on the humidity and temperature. In general, increased watering frequency is necessary in the summer, as opposed to the winter when growth slows down. Drenching the entire plant and allowing excess water to drain off is recommended. Always ensure good air circulation to prevent any rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platycerium superbum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch the fronds, leading to damage, so it should ideally be placed in a spot where it receives filtered light. In natural settings, they grow under canopies which provide dappled sunlight, simulating this environment indoors is beneficial. An east or north-facing window where the light is bright but not direct for extended periods works well. Additionally, the plant can adapt to lower light conditions, but its growth will be slower and may affect its overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Platycerium superbum is minimal and usually involves removing dead or diseased fronds to maintain its health and appearance. Care should be taken when pruning, as the basal fronds, which form a kind of shield, should not be removed unless absolutely necessary, as they are crucial for nutrient absorption and plant stability. Instead, focus on cutting back the antler or fertile fronds if they become brown or damaged. Always use clean, sharp scissors or shears to prevent disease spread. Regular observation and light pruning will keep it tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Stag Horn Fern","description":"Platycerium superbum, commonly known as the staghorn fern, is a Platycerium species of fern. It is native to Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Stag Horn Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal infections","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Platycerium superbum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Bark based","Sphagnum moss"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged. During warmer months, increase the frequency of watering to compensate for faster evaporation. It's best to use rainwater or distilled water to avoid the buildup of minerals that can be harmful to the plant. Always check the top inch of the soil; if it feels dry, it's time to water again. During cooler months, reduce watering slightly, allowing the soil to dry out a bit more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Urtica ferox, or tree nettle, thrives in partial shade to full sun environments. When growing this plant, ensure it receives direct sunlight for a portion of the day to stimulate healthy growth, but it should also have access to shade to protect it from scorching. If growing indoors, place it near a bright window with filtered light. In outdoor settings, consider locations where it can find respite from the midday sun. Adapt the sunlight exposure according to seasonal changes, with more sunlight during cooler months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning tree nettles should be done with caution due to their stinging hairs. Wear protective gloves and long sleeves when handling the plant. Pruning is best carried out in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. If the plant becomes too bushy or overgrown, selectively prune to improve airflow and shape the plant as desired. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the plant at a time, as this can stress the plant and inhibit growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tree Nettle","description":"Urtica ferox, commonly known as tree nettle, or ongaonga in Māori, is a nettle that is endemic to New Zealand. It is sometimes known as \"Taraonga\", \"Taraongaonga\" or \"Okaoka\". Unlike other herbaceous species in the Urtica genus, ongaonga is a large woody shrub. It has woody stems and unusually large stinging spines that can result in a painful sting that lasts several days. The shrub can grow to a height of 3 m (9.8 ft) with the base...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Tree Nettle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Urtica ferox"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14757,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polemonium viscosum prefers consistent moisture and should not be allowed to dry out completely. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During warmer months, you may need to increase the frequency of watering, while in cooler months, reduce watering slightly as the plant's growth slows down. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool. Avoid letting the plant sit in water, especially in saucers or trays, to prevent overwatering issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polemonium viscosum thrives in bright conditions with some protection from intense, direct midday sun. Ideally, it should be grown in a spot where it can receive either full sun in the cooler parts of the day (such as morning sun) and then some shade during the hottest part of the afternoon, or alternatively, in dappled sunlight throughout the day. Too much direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, can scorch the leaves, so finding a balance between enough light for blooming and some shade is key. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Polemonium viscosum primarily involves removing spent flowers and damaged or dead foliage to encourage further blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. Deadheading, or cutting off the faded blooms, will prolong the flowering period and redirect energy into producing new blooms. Once the flowering season is over, cut back the plant to tidy it up and promote bushier growth in the next season. Always use clean and sharp pruning shears to avoid disease transmission. Pruning can also help improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sky pilot","description":"Polemonium viscosum, known by the common names sky pilot, skunkweed, sticky Jacobs-ladder, sticky polemonium, is a flowering plant in the genus Polemonium native to western North America from southern British Columbia east to Montana and south to Arizona and New Mexico, where it grows at high altitudes on dry, rocky sites.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["sky pilot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Polemonium viscosum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning or late afternoon, but avoid intense, midday sun which might scorch the leaves. This plant does well in an indoor setting near a south or east-facing window, where it can receive a few hours of sunlight daily. When grown outdoors, providing partial shade during the hottest hours will help keep the plant healthy. Insufficient light can cause the plant to become leggy, while too much direct sunlight can lead to leaf burn. Adjust the light conditions according to your plant’s responses."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula muscosa helps maintain its shape and encourages denser growth. This plant can be pruned any time of the year; however, the ideal time is during its primary growing season in spring and early summer. After pruning, allow the cut stems to dry for a couple of days to prevent rot before replanting or further watering. This plant easily propagates from stem cuttings, so use the trimmed sections to grow new plants."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"lizard's-tail","description":"Crassula muscosa (Linnaeus, 1760), also named Crassula lycopodioides (Lamarck) or Crassula pseudolycopodioides, is a succulent plant native to South Africa and Namibia, belonging to the family of Crassulaceae and to the genus Crassula.
