{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14659,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Atrichum undulatum prefers consistently moist conditions, so it's important to water it regularly but not excessively to avoid waterlogging. It thrives in humid environments, so mimicking these conditions can be beneficial. Ensure the soil remains damp to the touch, particularly during dry periods. Ideally, use rainwater or distilled water to avoid any chemicals from tap water that may hinder its growth. Keep an eye on your plant to prevent it from drying out, especially if it's kept indoors, where humidity levels are often lower."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Atrichum undulatum thrives in partial to full shade conditions. Direct sunlight can be too harsh and can cause the plant to dry out or become scorched. Ideally, the plant should receive indirect light or dappled sunlight, similar to the conditions of a forest understory. If indoors, place it in a north or east-facing window where it can receive gentle morning sunlight. Ensuring appropriate lighting will help maintain its lush, green appearance and support overall health. Adjust lighting based on observations of the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a moss species, Atrichum undulatum doesn't require traditional pruning like many other plants. However, you may wish to trim back any sections that appear to be yellowing or dead to encourage new growth and maintain its health. This can improve air circulation and light penetration, which are essential for the plant's vitality. Use clean scissors or shears to minimize the risk of introducing disease. Regularly removing fallen debris can also help keep the plant looking tidy and prevent mold growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Catherine's moss","description":"Atrichum undulatum is a species of mosses belonging to the family Polytrichaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Catherine's moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Atrichum undulatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15053,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eriophorum vaginatum, often found in wet environments, requires consistently moist soil conditions to thrive. Water this plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, similar to its natural bog habitat. During dry periods, increase watering frequency, avoiding waterlogged soil, which can cause root rot. In container settings, ensure proper drainage while maintaining moisture levels. Employ a saucer under pots to capture excess water, promoting a humid environment. It's crucial to observe local weather conditions and adjust watering schedules accordingly, aiming to mimic the plant's natural moisture-rich environment without overwhelming its roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriophorum vaginatum prefers conditions of full to partial sunlight, replicating its natural open meadow or wetland habitat. Optimal growth occurs when it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, ensure bright, indirect light to maintain its characteristic fluffy seed heads. Regularly monitor its exposure to ensure it's consistent with its native preferences, considering its adaptability to both sunlight and mild shading."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eriophorum vaginatum is not generally required for health but can help maintain appearance and prevent seed spread if desired. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy new growth. If the plant becomes too dense or starts to decline, you can thin out the older stalks to improve air circulation and encourage fresh growth. Cutting back spent flower heads before seeds are set can help control its spread in managed landscapes. Avoid heavy pruning, as this species relies on its full foliage coverage for health and aesthetic purposes."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"tussock cottongrass","description":"Eriophorum vaginatum, the hare's-tail cottongrass, tussock cottongrass, or sheathed cottonsedge, is a species of perennial herbaceous flowering plant in the sedge family Cyperaceae. It is native to bogs and other acidic wetlands throughout the Holarctic Kingdom. It is a 30–60 cm high tussock-forming plant with solitary spikes.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Europe","North America","Asia"],"other_name":["tussock cottongrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Eriophorum vaginatum"],"soil":["Acidic","Peat","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15254,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hesperaloe parviflora, also known as Red Yucca, is drought tolerant and requires infrequent watering. During the growing season, water the plant deeply but allow the soil to dry between waterings; approximately every 2-3 weeks. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant is more susceptible to root rot if overwatered. Always ensure the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hesperaloe parviflora thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant blooms, it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. The plant is well-suited to hot and arid environments, making it ideal for desert gardens. If grown in partial shade, expect fewer flowers and slower growth. Planting in a location with ample sunlight will ensure the best display of its tubular red flowers, which attract hummingbirds and other pollinators."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hesperaloe parviflora is minimal but beneficial for maintaining appearance and encouraging new growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them at the base, using clean, sharp shears to prevent disease. After flowering, you can cut the flower stalks close to the ground to tidy up the plant, even though leaving them intact won't harm the plant. Annual removal of dead flower stalks will encourage more blooms next season and keep the plant's energy focused on new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red yucca","description":"Hesperaloe parviflora, also known as red yucca, hummingbird yucca, redflower false yucca and samandoque, is a plant that is native to Chihuahuan desert of west Texas east and south into central and south Texas and northeastern Mexico around Coahuila.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Texas","Northeastern Mexico"],"other_name":["red yucca"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hesperaloe parviflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In cultivation or research settings, maintaining a damp environment without water saturation is crucial. Mist with water lightly to replicate natural moisture conditions. Avoid overwatering, as excessive water can disrupt the delicate balance this lichen needs to thrive. If grown outdoors, the natural ecosystem often provides adequate moisture, but in drier climates, supplemental moisture through misting can help maintain optimal conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lichenomphalia umbellifera prefers partial to full shade, as excessive direct sunlight can be harmful to its delicate structure. Mimic its natural habitat, typically found in moist, shaded environments like forest floors. If grown indoors or in controlled environments, place it in areas where it receives filtered light or indirect sunlight, which helps prevent dehydration and damage. Ensuring that the ambient environment remains cool and shaded will help maintain the moisture balance this lichen needs, promoting its growth and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Lichenomphalia umbellifera as it is a lichen rather than a traditional plant. Instead of growing stems and leaves, it forms a symbiotic relationship between fungi and algae. Any pruning or cleaning should focus on gently removing debris or dead material without disturbing the living organism. If necessary, use tweezers or a soft brush to carefully cleanup without applying pressure, ensuring that the lichen's body remains intact. This low-maintenance approach respects the unique biology of this species, allowing it to grow naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lichen Agaric","description":"Lichenomphalia umbellifera is a species of agaric fungus in the family Hygrophoraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Temperate regions worldwide"],"other_name":["Lichen Agaric"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lichenomphalia umbellifera"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15751,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stachys coccinea, commonly known as Texas Betony, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. It’s important to let the top layer of soil dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During hotter months, increase watering frequency slightly, but always ensure the soil doesn't remain soggy. Reduce watering in the winter when growth slows down, allowing the plant to rest. Take care not to water the foliage directly as it can encourage disease, instead focus on the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stachys coccinea thrives in full sun to partial shade, requiring at least six hours of sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, in hotter climates or during peak summer, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from the harshest rays and prevent wilting. In areas with milder summers, Stachys coccinea can enjoy full sunlight throughout the day. If grown indoors or in an area with less natural light, consider supplementing with a grow light for consistent growth. Position this plant in a spot where it can receive bright, indirect light if full sun is too intense."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Stachys coccinea to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to promote continued blooming throughout the season. At the end of the growing season, you can trim the plant back to about half its size to prevent leggy growth and prepare it for winter. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year. In early spring, a more substantial prune can stimulate fresh growth. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent disease spread. Pruning helps to refresh the plant and sustain its ornamental appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"scarlet hedgenettle","description":"Stachys coccinea, the scarlet hedgenettle or Texas betony, is an ornamental plant of the family Lamiaceae, which is native from Arizona to Texas and from Baja California Sur, Mexico to Nicaragua.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["scarlet hedgenettle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Stachys coccinea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15451,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum erianthum prefers consistently moist soil, so it's important to water it regularly, but ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Water deeply once or twice a week, depending on the environmental conditions and soil type. Do not let the soil dry out completely between waterings, but avoid keeping it too soggy as well. During hotter months or in dry climates, increase the frequency of watering. Always check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry, it's time to water. Maintaining the right moisture balance is key to healthy growth for this plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum erianthum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote healthy growth and flowering. If planted indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive bright light. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. However, if the plant receives too little sunlight, its growth may become leggy and sparse. Adjust the light exposure according to the plant's response and environmental conditions to ensure optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum erianthum involves removing any dead or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and improve air circulation. It is best to prune during the dormant season or right after the plant flowers. Use sharp and clean pruning shears to make clean cuts at a slight angle. Trim any overgrown branches to help maintain the desired shape and size of the plant. Regular pruning will encourage bushier growth and can help prevent any potential pest or disease issues by improving airflow through the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"potato tree","description":"Solanum erianthum is a species of nightshade that is native to southern North America and northern South America. It has been introduced to other parts of the world and has a nearly pantropical distribution. Common names include potatotree, mullein nightshade (that may also refer to S. donianum), velvet nightshade, and salvadora. The potatoes are not the fruits of the trees, they are the leaves.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["potato tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solanum erianthum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14559,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Angiopteris evecta, commonly known as the giant fern, prefers consistently moist conditions. It is vital to keep the soil evenly moist without letting it become waterlogged. This plant is native to tropical rainforests, so it thrives with high humidity and regular watering. Ensure the soil is well-draining to avoid root rot. During the hotter months or if kept indoors in dry environments, more frequent watering may be necessary to maintain the required humidity levels and prevent the fronds from wilting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The giant fern thrives in shaded to partially shaded environments, similar to the dappled sunlight found in its natural rainforest habitat. It prefers indirect sunlight, as direct sun exposure can scorch its fronds. When grown indoors, it's best to place the fern near a window with filtered light or in a room with bright, indirect light. Avoid placing it near south-facing windows where it might receive too much direct sun. Ensuring proper lighting will help maintain the lush growth and vibrant green color of the fronds."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Angiopteris evecta involves removing any dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain its appearance. Cut back any yellowing or brown fronds at the base using a pair of sharp, sterilized pruning shears. Regularly check for any signs of disease or pests as well. Pruning is generally minimal with this fern as it grows large naturally, but removing older, non-productive fronds can encourage more vigorous growth of new fronds and maintain overall plant health."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"king fern","description":"Angiopteris evecta, commonly known as the giant fern, is a rare plant occurring in eastern and northern Australia and the Malay Peninsula. Also found growing in nearby islands such as Borneo, Sumatra, New Guinea and various places in Polynesia, Melanesia and Madagascar. Listed as endangered in New South Wales, where it has been recorded growing in sub tropical rainforest, in the valley of the Tweed River. It is an invasive species in Hawaii and Jamaica.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia","Asia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["king fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Angiopteris evecta"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Rich","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14855,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Baptisia alba, also known as White Wild Indigo, is a drought-tolerant perennial that has relatively low water needs. Mist the substrate lightly with water daily or use a humidity tent to prevent it from drying out. Avoid overwatering, as waterlogged conditions can lead to contamination or the growth of unwanted fungi. Maintaining a balance in moisture is critical for healthy development and fruiting of lion's mane mushrooms."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hericium americanum, as a mushroom species, does not require sunlight for growth since mushrooms do not photosynthesize. Instead, they require tight control of their environmental conditions, typified by low light or indirect light settings. When cultivating indoors, ambient room light is usually sufficient. Direct sunlight should be avoided, as it can dry out the growth medium and negatively impact humidity levels, which are crucial for the development of lion's mane mushrooms. Maintaining consistent low-light conditions will help encourage healthy growth patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't necessary in the traditional sense for Hericium americanum, as it's a type of fungus. However, you do need to harvest the fruiting bodies at the right time for optimal edibility and to promote further growth. The best time to harvest is when the spines are well-formed but before they begin to dry out or discolor. Using a clean knife or scissors, cut the fruiting body from the substrate. It's important to handle them gently, as the spines are delicate and can easily break. Regular harvesting encourages more fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bear's Head Tooth","description":"Hericium americanum, commonly known as the bear's head tooth fungus, is an edible mushroom in the tooth fungus group. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15552,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus engelmannii, commonly known as Engelmann's pine, thrives in well-drained soils and requires moderate watering, especially during its initial establishment phase. Once the tree is established, it becomes more drought-tolerant, but it still benefits from occasional deep watering during prolonged dry periods. It's crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Avoid overwatering, as pines do not like soggy soil conditions. Adjust your watering schedule based on the local climate and seasonal rainfall, ensuring that the tree receives sufficient moisture without becoming waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus engelmannii prefers full sun exposure to thrive and develop its characteristic shape and needle density. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This tree is well-adapted to bright and open landscapes, and insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and a sparse canopy. If planting in a residential area, choose a location that does not cast prolonged shade on the pine. Adequate sunlight not only supports healthy growth but also helps prevent disease issues related to poor air circulation and dampness in shaded areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinus engelmannii should be minimal and primarily focuses on removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain the tree's health and promote better air circulation. Avoid heavy pruning or altering the tree's natural shape, as this can stress the pine. The best time to prune is during the late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Clean, sharp pruning tools are essential to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of infection. Regularly remove any dead needles and small branches to keep the tree tidy and healthy, but overall, this pine requires little pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Apache pine","description":"Pinus engelmannii, commonly known as the Apache pine, is a tree of Northern Mexico, in the Sierra Madre Occidental with its range extending a short distance into the United States in southwestern New Mexico and southeastern Arizona. This pine is a medium-sized species with a height of 20–30 m (66–98 ft) and a trunk diameter of 35–80 cm (14–31 in).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["Apache pine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Bark Beetles","Pine Tip Moth","Pine Needle Scale"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pinus engelmannii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Its common names include earleaf nightshade (or \"ear-leaved nightshade\"), woolly nightshade, flannel weed, bugweed, tobacco weed, tobacco bush, wild tobacco...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["bugweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Solanum mauritianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid cutting the flowering spurs (short flowering stems), as new blooms will form on these. A site that provides morning sun and afternoon shade is ideal to mimic its natural habitat. In general, find a balance between light and shaded conditions to keep this plant healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Astrantia major helps to encourage more blooms and maintain plant shape. After the flowering period, usually from early summer to early autumn, deadhead the spent blooms to prolong the flowering season and keep the plant tidy. In late autumn, you can cut back the foliage to ground level as the plant goes dormant, which also helps to reduce pest issues. In early spring, inspect for any winter damage and remove dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth. Regular pruning also helps to prevent self-seeding if you wish to control its spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"great masterwort","description":"Astrantia major, common name great masterwort, is a species of flowering plant in the family Apiaceae, native to central and eastern Europe. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14458,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiranthes lacera, commonly known as the Northern Slender Lady's Tresses, prefers soil that is kept consistently moist. It is important to ensure that the soil does not dry out completely, especially during its growing season, which typically occurs in the spring and summer months. However, care should be taken to avoid overwatering, as this can cause root rot. Therefore, maintaining a balance by watering moderately and ensuring good drainage is crucial for the optimal growth of this orchid species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiranthes lacera thrives in partial to full sunlight, though it generally prefers a partially shaded environment, especially in hotter climates. Ideally, provide this plant with morning sunlight followed by afternoon shade to simulate its natural habitat conditions. If growing indoors, place the pot near an east or west-facing window where it can receive several hours of indirect sunlight each day. Be cautious of prolonged exposure to intense sunlight, as it can scorch the leaves, reducing the plant's vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Spiranthes lacera is generally minimal. After the flowering period, usually in late summer, it's recommended to remove any dead or dried flower spikes to encourage further blooming and prevent unnecessary energy expenditure by the plant. Ensure that you use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid any damage to the plant or introduction of disease. Additionally, removing any yellow or damaged leaves can help maintain the overall health and appearance of the plant. Regular inspection for pests and cleaning of debris around the plant is also beneficial."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Slender Ladies' Tresses","description":"Spiranthes lacera, commonly called the slender ladies'-tresses, is a species of orchid that is native to Eastern North America. It has a widespread range and is found in a variety of open habitats, both natural and disturbed. It produces a spiral of white flowers in the summer.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Slender Ladies' Tresses"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Spiranthes lacera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14361,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pterygodium catholicum, being an orchid species, prefers consistent moisture but should not be left in standing water, as this can lead to root rot. Water this plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. This might mean watering once a week during the growing season and reducing frequency during the dormant period. It is important to use room temperature water, and rainwater or distilled water is preferred, as they are less likely to cause mineral build-up which can harm the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pterygodium catholicum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can be too harsh and may scorch the leaves, so it's ideal to place the plant near a window with filtered light or in a location where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with artificial light. The plant should receive about 10-12 hours of light daily to support its growth and flowering. Monitor the plant closely, as insufficient light may cause leggy growth, while excessive light may lead to leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pterygodium catholicum primarily involves removing dead or yellowing leaves and spent flower stems to maintain plant health and appearance. This should be done with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent the spread of diseases. Always cut back to the base of the plant or nearest healthy node. Pruning can encourage new growth and flowering, and is typically conducted during the plant's dormant period to minimize stress. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can negatively impact the plant's growth and orchid's ability to photosynthesize efficiently."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cowl Bonnet","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cowl Bonnet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pterygodium catholicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15453,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Watering Nyssa biflora, also known as swamp tupelo, should be done with care to mimic its natural habitat. This tree thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in swampy or wetland areas. Therefore, it requires consistent moisture. During dry spells or drought conditions, ensure that it receives adequate water to keep the soil consistently damp, but not waterlogged. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. The plant benefits from a good layer of mulch which helps retain soil moisture and maintain a cool root environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nyssa biflora thrives best in full sun to part shade conditions. Ideally, it should be planted in an area where it can receive at least four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. It tolerates shade, especially when grown in its natural habitat near water sources, but for optimal growth and vibrant fall foliage, more sunlight is preferable. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Ensuring a well-lit environment will also promote flowering and overall tree vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nyssa biflora is generally minimal since it naturally develops a good structure. However, it's useful to remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain its health. This can be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. If shape improvements are desired, you can selectively thin the canopy to allow light penetration, but be careful to maintain the natural form of the tree. Avoid heavy pruning as the tree may be slow to recover, and ensure tools are sterilized to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swamp tupelo","description":"Nyssa biflora, commonly referred to as the swamp tupelo, or swamp black-gum is a species of tupelo that lives in wetland habitats. Swamp tupelo grows chiefly in the coastal plains from Delaware, eastern Maryland, and southeastern Virginia, south to southern Florida and west to eastern Texas. Its range extends north up the Mississippi Valley to southern Arkansas and west and south Tennessee.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["Swamp tupelo"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Heart rot","Canker"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Nyssa biflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14759,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Akebia quinata prefers soil that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, typically spring through early autumn, it is crucial to water the plant regularly to keep the soil from drying out completely. However, reduce watering significantly during winter when the plant is dormant. If the plant is grown in a container, ensure that it has good drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture, especially in warm weather. Always let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Akebia quinata thrives in full sun to partial shade, performing best with at least a few hours of direct sunlight daily. It is adaptable and can tolerate shady conditions, but optimal flowering and fruiting occur in sunnier spots. In regions with hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. Ideal locations are those that receive morning sun with some protection during the harsh afternoon rays. When planted in full shade, expect reduced flowering and slower growth. Adapt the sunlight exposure according to the climate, ensuring balanced growth throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Akebia quinata to control its size and encourage bushier growth, especially if it is used for structural support like trellises or pergolas. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain an open and manageable framework. Cutting back overgrown stems will stimulate new shoots and can help contain its vigorous growth. Regular pruning keeps the vine tidy and prevents it from becoming unruly, especially since it can spread rapidly under favorable conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Five-leaf akebia","description":"Akebia quinata, commonly known as chocolate vine, five-leaf chocolate vine, or five-leaf akebia, is a shrub that is native to Japan, China and Korea, and naturalized in the eastern United States from Georgia to Michigan to Massachusetts.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Five-leaf akebia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Akebia quinata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Fungi get their moisture and nutrients from the decaying materials they grow upon. Therefore, if cultivating in a controlled environment for study or admiration, maintaining a moist substrate without over-saturating is crucial. Mist the mycelium or substrate lightly if it appears dry, avoiding direct soaking, to mimic the natural moist conditions this fungus might find in its habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pholiota velaglutinosa, as a fungus, does not require direct sunlight for growth. Instead of traditional sunlight, fungi thrive in environments with diffused light or even low-light conditions. When cultivating fungi such as this, focus on providing a dim environment that mimics forest or underwood settings where light is filtered. Bright, direct sunlight can be detrimental as it might dry out the substrate and inhibit fruiting body formation. Maintain a stable temperature and humidity level to simulate the natural ecosystem it typically grows in."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning, in the traditional sense applied to plants, is not applicable to fungi like Pholiota velaglutinosa. Instead, focus on managing the environment where the fungus grows. Regularly check for unwanted mold or contaminants in the substrate or growing area. Harvest mature mushrooms by gently twisting or cutting the base near the substrate to encourage fresh growth. General maintenance involves occasionally refreshing the substrate once the nutrients are depleted to promote continuous healthy production of the fungus, ensuring optimal growth conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Pholiota velaglutinosa is a species of agaric fungus in the family Strophariaceae. Found in the western United States, it was described as new to science in 1968 by American mycologists Alexander H. Smith and Lexemuel Ray Hesler. Fruit bodies have sticky reddish caps measuring 3–6 cm (1.2–2.4 in) in diameter. This plant does not tolerate drought well, so it's important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during dry spells. Water the plant when the top layer of soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring that it has adequate drainage to prevent waterlogging. Regular watering is crucial during the growing season in spring and summer, while less frequent watering is needed in fall and winter, when the plant's growth slows down. Always use room temperature water to avoid shocking the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola canina thrives best in a partially shaded environment, although it can tolerate some direct sunlight. Ideally, provide it with morning sun and afternoon shade, as too much direct and intense sunlight can scorch its delicate leaves and reduce flowering. If planted in a garden, choose a location with dappled sunlight—a woodland edge or beneath deciduous trees can be ideal. During particularly hot summer days, ensure the plant remains in the shade to keep it cool and avoid stress. Indoors, a spot near a north or east-facing window would be suitable."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Viola canina, minimal pruning is usually necessary. In general, you should remove spent flowers and old foliage to encourage new growth and potentially prolong the blooming period. Deadheading, or cutting off faded flowers, can help to improve the overall appearance of the plant and prevent unwanted self-seeding, which this species is prone to. In late autumn, trim back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Be careful not to prune too heavily, as this can hinder the plant’s natural growth and flowering cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Heath Dog-Violet","description":"Viola canina (heath dog-violet or heath violet) is a species of the genus Viola, native to Europe, where it is found in the uplands of box hill in Dorset, heaths, fens, and moist woodlands, especially on acidic soils.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Heath Dog-Violet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Viola canina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It does not need traditional watering like other plants. Instead, it's crucial to manage the moisture levels of the host plants, rather than the dodder itself. Keeping host plants healthy and well-watered will, inadvertently, ensure that Cuscuta gronovii receives the water it requires. In most cases, extra watering beyond regular maintenance of the host is unnecessary, as Cuscuta gronovii relies on the hydration of its host."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cuscuta gronovii does not have specific sunlight requirements, as it derives energy and nutrients from its host plant. Instead, its light needs are indirectly determined by the preferences of the host. Typically, it thrives in environments that are conducive to the growth of its hosts, which can vary widely. If managing or controlling its growth, consider its propensity to thrive in sunny to partially shaded areas where host plants are healthy. Reducing sunlight may not directly affect the dodder but may impact its host's growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cuscuta gronovii involves managing its growth to prevent it from overwhelming host plants or spreading to unwanted areas. Regularly inspect the host plant for new dodder growth and carefully cut it back as needed. Remove any seed pods before they mature to control its spread. Because it's a parasite, consider removing it from plants where it might cause harm. Thoroughly bag and dispose of pruned material to prevent reseeding or further spreading. Consistent monitoring is essential to effectively manage and control its growth."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Scaldweed","description":"Cuscuta gronovii is a yellow vine that grows as a parasite off of other plants. A deep, infrequent watering regimen encourages deep root growth and overall resilience."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus nigra thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If positioned in too much shade, the tree may become sparse and less vigorous. Therefore, when choosing a location for planting, ensure that it's in an open space that receives plenty of light, especially during the morning and early afternoon."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinus nigra should be done primarily to remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches and to maintain shape. Avoid cutting back the main leader or excessively pruning as this can affect the tree's natural shape and health. If you need to manage the size, lightly trim the ends of branches during the growing season to stimulate denser foliage. Adequate sunlight helps in producing vibrant flowers which are characteristic of this species. In partially shaded areas, while the plant may still grow, the flowering could be less prolific. Therefore, choosing a planting location that captures maximum sunlight throughout the day is beneficial. In naturally wooded or partially shaded environments, ensure that sunlight reaches the plant during the critical parts of the day to support its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sabatia brevifolia is relatively straightforward and mainly involves deadheading spent blooms to encourage additional flowering. It is an annual that grows in moist flatwoods and savannahs. It grows from 1-3 feet tall and the flowers have five white petals with pointed tips.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Shortleaf Rose Gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Sabatia brevifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14564,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Monstera deliciosa prefers its soil to be kept consistently moist but not soggy. Water the plant when the top 1-2 inches of soil are dry, typically once a week, but this can vary depending on the environment. You should reduce watering in the winter when the plant's growth slows. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure proper drainage by using a well-aerated potting mix and a pot with a drainage hole. Additionally, try to use room-temperature water to avoid shocking the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Monstera deliciosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sun can scorch its leaves, so it's best kept near a window filtered through a sheer curtain or in a place with morning sun. While it can tolerate lower light conditions, growth might be slower, and the plant may not develop its characteristic leaf splits or \"fenestrations.\" If you notice the plant leaning towards the light, rotate the pot periodically to encourage even growth. Consistent light conditions will help the plant flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Monstera deliciosa is important for controlling its size and encouraging new growth. Regularly remove any yellow or damaged leaves, cutting them at the base where they join the stem. You can also trim back healthy leaves if they're becoming too large or unruly, always cutting just after a node to promote new growth. Late winter to early spring is the ideal time for pruning as the plant responds well and begins its growth cycle. Use clean, sharp shears to minimize stress and the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swiss Cheese Plant","description":"Monstera deliciosa is a species of flowering plant native to tropical forests of southern Mexico, south to Panama. It has been introduced to many tropical areas, and has become a mildly invasive species in Hawaii, Seychelles, Ascension Island and the Society Islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Panama","Costa Rica"],"other_name":["Swiss Cheese Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Monstera deliciosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Additionally, pruning can help control the plant’s spread and reduce competition with surrounding grasses if it becomes too aggressive. Instead, it grows best in shaded or low-light conditions that mimic the forest floor or environments with indirect light. Bright, direct sunlight can cause dehydration and inhibit growth. Ensure that it is kept away from harsh sunlight and instead provide a setting that is consistently cool and partially shaded."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Psathyrella longipes as it is a mushroom and does not have branches or leaves like typical plants. Water it regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry spells. However, avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. It is crucial to ensure good drainage to prevent water from stagnating around the roots. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain an even moisture level. During hot, dry periods, additional watering may be necessary to ensure the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola rotundifolia thrives in partial to full shade. It naturally grows in forested areas, meaning it does not tolerate prolonged periods of direct sunlight well. The plant flourishes under dappled sunlight or in areas with only morning sun exposure. Overexposure to direct sunlight can lead to scorched leaves and poor growth. Providing a location with filtered light or shaded areas under taller trees or a structure will help maintain its foliage color and flowering potential. Ensuring it is shielded from harsh midday sun is crucial for its survival and overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Viola rotundifolia is minimal, primarily involving the removal of dead or wilted leaves and spent flowers to encourage healthy growth and potentially more blooms. After the flowering period, trim back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain a neat appearance and prevent diseases. If the plant becomes too dense, thinning can improve air circulation. Regular cleanup of the plant also deters pests and maintains its aesthetic value. It's best to use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant tissue while pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Round-leaved Violet","description":"Viola rotundifolia, common name roundleaf yellow violet, is a plant species of the genus Viola. In the cooler months, you can reduce the watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down, but never allow the soil to dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea hederifolia thrives in full sunlight, needing at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to produce its vibrant red flowers. If growing indoors, place the plant in a bright windowsill or under a grow light to mimic its preferred sunny conditions. Adequate sunlight exposure is key to healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Ipomoea hederifolia to encourage a bushier growth habit and to control its size, as it can become quite vigorous. Trim back overly long stems and remove any dead or damaged foliage. It is ideal to prune during the spring before the flowering season or in late fall after blooming ends. Regular pruning will also help to improve air circulation within the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Maintain cleanliness of your pruning tools to prevent any potential spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"scarlet creeper","description":"Ipomoea hederifolia is a species of herbaceous annual vine native to the Americas.
